title: Wireless Era
intro: The Wireless Era marked Singapore's decisive shift from fixed-line broadband to mobile internet access. Government-led infrastructure programmes combined with global hardware innovations — most notably Apple's iPhone — fundamentally transformed how Singaporeans connected to and used the internet.

milestones.detail: Third-generation (3G) mobile internet becomes available in Singapore, enabling mobile data access for the first time. By March 2006, there were already around 317,600 3G subscribers, representing 7% of the local population.

The government-led Wireless@SG programme, announced by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in October 2006, begins operation on 1 December 2006 — a month ahead of schedule. It deploys free public Wi-Fi hotspots across 7,500 locations by 2008, and has since grown to over 44,000 locations island-wide.
milestones.image_alt: Wireless@SG public Wi-Fi signage in Singapore

milestones.detail: The release of the original Apple iPhone catalysed a massive shift in how Singaporeans used the internet, driving explosive demand for mobile data and app-based services.
Fourth-generation (4G LTE) mobile internet rolls out in Singapore, delivering significantly faster mobile speeds and enabling richer mobile experiences for consumers and businesses alike.
